Title: Gaussian-like integral : $\int_0^{\infty} e^{-x^2} \cos( a x) \ \mathrm{d}x$
Content:
Prove that : $$ \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2} e^{-\frac{a^2}{4} } =\int_0^{\infty} e^{-x^2} \cos( a x) \ \mathrm{d}x$$ the only thing I can think of is differentiating the RHS and trying to get : $$ -2 f'(a) =a f(a) $$
But I couldn't do it. 
Can anyone show me how to do this ?
AcceptedAnswer:
Differential Equation Approach Note that since the integrand is even we have $$
\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x
=\frac12\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x\tag1
$$ Then differentiating with respect to $a$ yields $$
\begin{align}
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}a}\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x
&=-\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}x\sin(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x\tag{2a}\\
&=\frac12\int_{-\infty}^\infty\sin(ax)\,\mathrm{d}e^{-x^2}\tag{2b}\\
&=-\frac12\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}\,\mathrm{d}\sin(ax)\tag{2c}\\
&=-\frac a2\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x\tag{2d}\\
\end{align}
$$ $\text{(2a)}$ : differentiate $\text{(2b)}$ : prepare to integrate by parts $\text{(2c)}$ : integrate by parts $\text{(2d)}$ : $\mathrm{d}\sin(ax)=a\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x$ Since $f'(a)=-\frac a2f(a)$ has the solution $f(a)=ce^{-a^2/4}$ and $f(0)=\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2}\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{\sqrt\pi}2$ , $$
\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{\sqrt\pi}{2}\,e^{-a^2/4}\tag3
$$ Contour Integral Approach $$
\begin{align}
\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x
&=\frac12\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}\cos(ax)\,\mathrm{d}x\tag{4a}\\
&=\frac12\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}e^{iax}\,\mathrm{d}x\tag{4b}\\
&=\frac12e^{-a^2/4}\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-\left(x-ia/2\right)^2}\,\mathrm{d}x\tag{4c}\\[3pt]
&=\frac{\sqrt\pi}2\,e^{-a^2/4}\tag{4d}
\end{align}
$$ $\text{(4a)}$ : symmetry $\text{(4b)}$ : $\sin(ax)$ is odd in $x$ $\text{(4c)}$ : complete the square $\text{(4d)}$ : Cauchy's Integral Theorem and $\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2}\,\mathrm{d}t=\sqrt\pi$
